org.activebpel.rt.axis.bpel.handlers
Class AeSimpleAuthenticationHandler

java.lang.Object
  org.apache.axis.handlers.BasicHandler
      org.activebpel.rt.axis.bpel.handlers.AeSimpleAuthenticationHandler
All Implemented Interfaces:
org.apache.axis.Handler, java.io.Serializable
public class AeSimpleAuthenticationHandler
extends org.apache.axis.handlers.BasicHandler

A slight change on Axis's authentication handler. The default Axis handler was throwing a fault if it was in the request flow and a request came in without authentication information. This implementation differs in that it allows unauthenticated requests to pass through but not until the user name is cleared on the message context. This will allow us to safely extract the principal and authenticate when possible or treat the request as unauthenticated.

See Also:
Serialized Form

authenticate

protected boolean authenticate(org.apache.axis.MessageContext aMsgContext)
                        throws org.apache.axis.AxisFault
Implements the authentication routine by way of the SecurityProvider that's installed on the context.

Parameters:
aMsgContext -
Returns:
true if the user was authenticated, false otherwise.
Throws:
org.apache.axis.AxisFault - thrown if the user was not authenticated

hasCredentials

protected boolean hasCredentials(org.apache.axis.MessageContext aMsgContext)
Returns true if the user name or password are present on the context. It's possible that the authentication scheme only requires one of these values in order to authenticate the user.

Parameters:
aMsgContext -

getProvider

protected org.apache.axis.security.SecurityProvider getProvider(org.apache.axis.MessageContext aMsgContext)
The security provider will have been set on the context if the inbound request passed through a security layer, otherwise we'll fallback on Axis's default which is file based.
